summary: influenza is a negative-strand RNA virus that uses aquatic birds as reservoir hosts. it is classified by the surface proteins hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) there are 16 HA and 9 NA subtypes, but not all combinations have been recovered from aquatic birds. type was low (4.4%), one market exhibited an unusually high prevalence (36.6%) chickens that were previously infected may have been partially protected from the pathogenicity induced by a HP H5N1-subtype virus. this could have allowed the HP H5N1-subtype virus to ‘silently’ attain a prevalence where transmission to humans was probable. samples were collected by taking oropharyngeal or cloacal swabs of birds or by collecting from feces, fecal digestors, water troughs, and standing water. each month, 300–600 total samples were collected across several locations. surveillance expanded to several villages in the area of the outbreak. influenza-positive eggs were detected by testing for hemagglutination of 0.5% chicken erythrocytes according to standard procedures. real-time RT-PCR (rRT-PCR) was selected as an alternative to virus isolation in eggs. 0.1 mL of a 110 dilution of infective egg chorioallantoic fluid in sterile PBS was intravenously injected into each of 10 six-week-old, specific pathogen-free chickens. individuals were scored on the basis of the observed morbidity (0 = normal, 1 = sick, 2 = severely sick, 3 = dead) a total of 1177 samples were tested for influenza A by virus isolation. none of the sampling sites were reported as an outbreak area during the study. sample screening samples were screened in 1 of 2 ways. hemagglutination inhibition (HI) assays were performed to determine the subtype of influenza-positive samples. a total of 5715 samples from several locations in Bangladesh were tested for AIV. the results of the virus isolation and rRT-PCR detection methods on identical samples were in agreement for 86.4% of the samples. cloacal and oropharyngeal swabs were collected from the same bird. the results agreed for 77.8% (n = 239) and 78.6% (n = 714) of the hosts. swabs were more likely to test positive than cloacal swabs were regardless of detection method. Exceptions include the lake, where the lesser whistling duck is the primary inhabitant, and the pet bird market. the H9 subtype was identified at most of the retail markets. 76.3% of rRT-PCR positive samples were also virus isolation positive. the estimated prevalence of the H9-subtype in Dhaka is 16.5%. isolates from Bangladesh reacted strongly to all of the anti-H9 sera. most of the isolates compared to the remaining sites to confirm that differences in prevalence exist. Exceptions include the lake, where the lesser whistling duck (Anatidae) is the primary inhabitant. most of the influenza isolates were H9-subtype viruses (94.2%) the H9 subtype was identified at most of the retail markets. the estimated prevalence of the H9-subtype in Dhaka is 16.5%. isolates from Bangladesh reacted strongly to all of the anti-H9 sera. most isolates reacted less strongly to the -G1 sera than to the remaining antisera. 640 320 2560 5120 1280 10240 5120 20480 A/Hong Kong/1073/99 320 320 1280 320 320 5120 5120 A/Turkey/Minnesota/38391-6/95 80 40 prevalence in the migratory waterfowl that visit the lake is extremely low (1.7%), which suggests that AIV might not be maintained in birds at the lake ecosystem. but the transmission within the flock appears to be at a minimum level as shown by the low prevalence at the site compared to that in the markets. subtype virus was isolated from a water trough in a chicken cage. it is more likely that the birds were infected prior to arrival at the market. this diversity increases the probability that reassortment could occur between influenza subtypes. the source of HP H5N1-subtype viruses in the bird markets cannot be determined. the chickens that were shedding the HP H5N1-subtype virus and the ducks from which the H5N1-infected fecal samples were collected were apparently healthy at the time of sampling. a single H9N2-subtype virus, A/Quail/Hong Kong/G1/97 (G1), was most similar to the HP H5N1 subtype from the 1997 outbreak in 6 of the 8 gene segments. a single H9N2-subtype virus, A/Duck/Hong Kong/Y280/97 (H9N2), was most similar to the HP H5N1 subtype from the 1997 outbreak. a number of H9N2-subtype viruses can transmit through direct contact with infected chickens and ferrets. it is this route of infection that likely produced the H9N2-subtype infections that have been reported in humans [6], [7], [22]. however, aerosol transmission has not been observed between ferrets that were infected with H9N2-subtype viruses, suggesting transmission between mammals is currently limited [34] the H9N2-subtype reassortant viruses have not established a stable lineage in the swine population. many isolates possess the L226 mutation in the receptor binding pocket of the HA1 protein. this mutation confers a higher degree of specificity to sialic acid residues that contain the human-like -2,6 linkage.
